entry.title: Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

 

Hello Everyone,

With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Sourcing and Procurement line of business continues to evolve, bringing forward innovations that empower procurement professionals to operate with greater agility, transparency, and collaboration. This release focuses on enhancing core procurement processes, integrating intelligent technologies, and improving user experience across the board. Letâ€™s take a closer look at the key updates and how they support your procurement transformation journey.

 

For other releases please see here. Check out all demos in a playlist here.

Operational Procurement

  • Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header
  • Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow
  • Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval
  • Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow
  • V4 API for intracompany stock transfer
  • Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes
  • Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App
  • Extensibility in manage source lists app
  • Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

  • Input tax â€“ Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

SAP Arabia Central Procurement

  • Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts
  • Procurement Expansion Package

 

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header

The integration of the Document Management System (DMS) at the header level of purchase requisitions marks a significant improvement in how procurement teams manage documentation. Professional purchasers can now attach relevant documents directly to requisitions, with the ability to classify them for internal or external use. While external classification will be supported in future updates, the current functionality already streamlines documentation processes and ensures consistency across SAP Fiori applications such as â€œManage Purchase Requisition â€“ Professionalâ€ and â€œCreate Purchase Requisition â€“ Advanced.â€ This enhancement simplifies audit trails, improves traceability, and fosters better collaboration between procurement teams and stakeholders.

 

For more information, see: Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional

Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow

Procurement workflows often require flexibility, especially when exceptional circumstances arise. The introduction of ad-hoc approvers allows authorized users to dynamically add individuals to a workflow instance based on the context of a specific purchase order. This capability ensures that critical decisions are not delayed due to rigid approval chains. The ability to designate multiple ad-hoc approvers and track their involvement in the approval history adds a layer of transparency and responsiveness, making procurement processes more agile and context-aware.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Orders 

Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval

SAP has introduced a reviewer step in purchase order workflows, allowing designated users to monitor workflow progress and provide feedback without having approval authority. This feature is particularly valuable for organizations that require compliance checks, financial oversight, or legal reviews before finalizing purchases. By enabling user-based or role-based recipient selection and allowing deadline settings, SAP ensures that the review process is both structured and adaptable. This innovation enhances governance and fosters a collaborative approach to procurement decision-making.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow

The ability to use account assignment categoriesâ€”such as Internal Order, Asset, and Sales Orderâ€”as workflow triggers provides organizations with granular control over procurement approvals. These categories can now be defined as start conditions for purchase order workflows, allowing organizations to tailor approval processes based on financial responsibility and operational context. Additionally, step conditions can be configured to assign specific individuals responsible for each category, ensuring that approvals are targeted and relevant. This supports better financial stewardship and operational alignment.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

 

V4 API for intracompany stock transfer

SAPâ€™s introduction of a new OData V4 API for intracompany stock transfers enables external applications to create, read, update, and delete stock transport orders in real time. This API-driven approach supports seamless integration with external systems, facilitating efficient stock movement across organizational units and enhancing data accuracy. The inclusion of error messaging ensures that invalid data is promptly flagged, reducing the risk of discrepancies and improving overall inventory control.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Stock Transport Order (CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001) and Stock Transport Order (OData V4)

Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes

Supplier collaboration is enhanced through the automatic integration of supplier confirmation notes into purchase orders. When suppliers provide notes during the confirmation process, these are now automatically transferred to the corresponding purchase order and its items. This ensures that supplier input is accurately captured and reflected throughout the procurement lifecycle. By reducing manual data entry and minimizing the risk of miscommunication, this feature improves order accuracy and strengthens supplier relationships.

 

For more information, see: Manage Supplier Confirmations

Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App

Project-based procurement receives a boost with the inclusion of account assignment category Q (project stock) in the Manage Purchase Contract app. This enables organizations to handle make-to-order scenarios with greater precision, including the management of fields such as WBS elements and GL accounts. By extending support to project procurement, SAP empowers industries like construction, engineering, and manufacturing to align purchasing activities with project timelines and budgets.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Contracts

Extensibility in manage source lists app

The Manage Source List app has been enhanced to support custom fields, allowing users to store business-specific information that aids in sourcing decisions. Previously, the app did not permit the addition of custom fields, limiting its flexibility. With the new capability, users can define fields of various typesâ€”such as string, date, and decimalâ€”and manage them using provided BADIs. This extensibility supports tailored data management and improves the efficiency of source list maintenance.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Source Lists and Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects

Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

Financial transparency is further improved with the ability to view pending invoice values distributed across account assignment splits in purchase order items. When a purchase order item is assigned to multiple cost objects, such as cost centers or internal orders, users can now monitor the open invoice amount proportionally per assignment line. This granular visibility supports accurate accruals, budget tracking, and financial reporting, enabling organizations to maintain tighter control over their expenditures.

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Purchase Order Items by Account Assignment 

Procurement Expansion Package

The Procurement Expansion Package (PEP) consolidates advanced operational procurement features, catalog content channels, and supplier network capabilities into a single offering. Designed for SAP Cloud ERP customers, PEP delivers comprehensive spend coverage, improved compliance, and enhanced supplier collaboration. It supports a consumer-grade shopping experience, touchless supplier interactions, and end-to-end visibility across procurement processes. By digitizing manual transactions and centralizing procurement data, PEP helps organizations achieve greater efficiency, transparency, and strategic value.

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

Input tax â€“ Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

Tax compliance is a critical aspect of procurement, and SAP addresses this through integration with external tax engines like Vertex and Thomson Reuters in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management. This integration allows for the calculation, verification, and validation of VAT, GST, and other transaction taxes on supplier invoices. By automating tax determination and comparison with supplier-provided data, organizations can prevent overpayments, mitigate compliance risks, and enhance audit readiness. The ability to specify commodity codes and use address data for tax calculation further refines the accuracy of this process.

 

 

For more information, see: Verification of Tax Applied to a Supplier Invoice

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Procurement

Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts

Central procurement capabilities have been expanded in two key areas. First, the activation of single-line distribution within central contracts allows organizations to generate individual outline agreements for each contract line item. This is particularly beneficial for industries such as automotive, where scheduling agreements often require single-item configurations. Second, when copying a central contract, users can now edit fields such as supplier and purchasing organization, providing greater flexibility in contract lifecycle management and enabling smoother transitions when suppliers change.

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing User Experience in SAP Guided Buying
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my latest blog. 

My name is Angeline Gregory, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the UK.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Guided Buying.

SAP Guided Buying can steer users towards more efficient and compliant buying processes.  It is crucial to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into your buying processes to enrich the experience.

The below features in SAP Guided Buying make purchasing decisions smoother and smarter and hence improve cost effectiveness and increases compliance.

Catalog Item Recommendation

The item recommendation feature suggests products and services based on users' past purchases.  It collects purchasing history from your organization and uses artificial intelligence to recommend catalog items that might be of interest based on the individual user. Item recommendations display in a carousel at the top of the home page, in the item details page or as alternatives to non-catalog item.

This feature improves productivity by:

  • Encouraging usage of catalog item when creating a non-catalog requestâ€‹
  • Reducing effort when searching for itemsâ€‹
  • Reducing distractions when browsing
  • Improving user experience â€‹

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_ITEM_RECOMMENDATIONS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription 
  • At first SAP Guided Buying will show â€œPopular Itemsâ€ based on organizationâ€™s most frequent purchases.  AI will learn and start showing â€œRecommended for youâ€ items / services based on users clicksâ€‹.

Guided Buying Usage Report

The usage report in Guided Buying gives administrators insight into user searches, purchases, and overall interaction with SAP Guided Buying. SAP Guided Buying generates this report monthly to provides usage details, such as the number of users who signed in, number of users who added items to their cart, total number of items added to carts, and searches that returned no results.  This report helps answer business questions like which catalog areas to expand and the most popular search items.  By leveraging the insights from the Usage Report, organizations can continuously improve user experience based on data.

This feature improves efficiency by:

  • Highlighting opportunities based on user behavior, search patternsâ€‹ and search effectiveness analysisâ€‹
  • Aids making catalog improvements and helps bring spend under managementâ€‹
  • Providing evidence- to make quicker design decisions

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • â€‹This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription
  • SAP Guided Buying generates reports only after at least 100 unique users have cumulatively clicked â€œAdd to cartâ€ more than 1,000 times.  It must first collect and analyze a significant number of searching and purchasing actions 

â€‹By using these features in guided buying systems, organizations can significantly help shape the way users buy goods or services.

Integrating AI and ML into guided buying isn't just about improving technology; it's about strategically enhancing the procurement process better suited to users' needs, while staying compliant and cost effective.

So, whether you are just starting out or looking to refine your procurement processes, consider how AI and ML can make a significant impact on your organization's guided buying system and watch as your bottom line and operational efficiencies improve.

Take the next steps by having a look at our comprehensive one-pager on AI and ML in SAP Guided Buying.

Thank you for reading my blog!!

entry.title: How Personal Spending Habits Mirror Enterprise Procurement
entry.content:
Introduction

When it comes to managing our personal finances, most of us intuitively follow certain steps to control spending and save more. Interestingly, these same steps closely mirror the structured procurement processes that enterprises use to manage spend at scale.

To illustrate, letâ€™s start with a simple personal example and then see how it aligns with enterprise procurement practices.

Personal Spend and Saving: A Simple Thought Process

Imagine you want to save more money this month. You realize there are two main ways to do that:

  1. Increase your income.       â¬†ï¸
  2. Reduce your expenses.     â¬‡ï¸

Letâ€™s focus on reducing expenses.

This logical sequence helps you save money while still ensuring your familyâ€™s needs are met.

How This Mirrors Enterprise Procurement

At the enterprise level, procurement follows the same flowâ€”only itâ€™s structured, automated, and scaled to handle greater complexity.

 

Personal Spend ExampleEnterprise Procurement Process
Classify expenses (e.g., groceries)Spend Classification: Categorize spend into goods and services like IT equipment, raw materials, or consulting services.
Analyze where you spend the mostSpend Analysis: Identify high-spend areas and uncover potential savings opportunities.
Search for vendorsSourcing: Conduct market research, invite bids (RFPs), and evaluate supplier capabilities.
Negotiate and select a vendorContracting: Negotiate terms (price, quality, delivery) and create legal contracts to formalize agreements.
Receive daily apple deliveryCataloging & Purchase Request: Maintain supplier catalogs for easy ordering and raise purchase requests as needed.
Receive invoice at month-endPurchase Order & Receipt: Issue purchase orders, confirm goods/services received, and match them with the invoice.
Pay the vendorInvoicing & Payment: Process, approve, and execute payments through financial systems.

Conclusion

Managing personal finances may seem worlds apart from enterprise procurement, but the underlying principles are remarkably similar. Both rely on classification, sourcing, negotiation, purchase, and payment to optimize spend while meeting essential needs.

The next time you shop for apples, youâ€™re not just budgeting - youâ€™re practicing procurement on a personal scale.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procurement Solutions for Lifesciences & Healthcare customers
entry.content:
In this post, we consider a common usecase for pharmaceutical companies: the procurement of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) from approved contract manufacturers (CMO) or suppliers.

User Story

As a production planner in a mid-size pharmaceutical company, I need to procure an API only from approved manufacturers (CMO), verify the regulatory documents for completeness, correctness, and validity, so that the purchase can be processed without compliance risks or delays.

Personas Involved

  • Production Planner (using MM on ERP)
  • Category Buyer (Using  SAP Ariba Category Management )
  • Quality Assurance Approver (using SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance & SAP Ariba Supplier Risk )
  • Supplier Manufacturer (using the SAP Business Network for Suppliers )
  • Supplier Risk Analyst (using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk)
  • AP Invoice Processor (SAP Ariba Invoicing

System Recommendations & Assumptions

  • Supplier/Contract Manufacturer can be sourced using Ariba Guided Sourcing and onboarded using SAP Ariba SLP , continuously monitored for risks (ESG, financial, regulatory, etc.) using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

 

  • Possibility to invite customers for a sourcing event in   SAP Ariba Sourcing, based on their qualification and risk status as well as ability to fulfill the business n
  • At the end of the sourcing event, a supplier will be selected.

The Supplier 360 dashboard on SLP can be used to view supplier details.

  • Suppliers can be qualified and registered using SLP, where status, certification information, risk information, etc., can be maintained and viewed. GxP relevant certificates (GMP certificate, DMF/CEP references, country-specific permits) can be used for supplier qualification.
  • Contracts can be created using baseline contract templates in Ariba.
  • The API material can be maintained in ERP with a unique material code. Manufacturerâ€™s substance codes and parent-child code mappings can also be maintained in ERP.

End-to-end Flow ( Considering PR originates in ERP, for direct material procurement) 

  • ERP:
    • MRP run creates a PR for API-12345 for supplier AKME Systems for 50 kgs with a delivery deadline of 4 weeks
  • PR Sent to Ariba Buying/Guided Buying :
    • The PR is sent to Ariba Buying/Guided Buying for collaboration and approvals.
    • Information related to parent-child codes mapping, a reference list of approved suppliers, etc. is also sent.
  • Category Buyer Review :
    • The category buyer in Ariba Guided Buying reviews the PR and confirms the supplier/manufacturer pairing.
    • Custom fields display required information like manufacturer's codes, parent code, DMF, etc.
  • QA Approval :
    • As part of QA approval, following checks could be considered: 
      • Ensuring the CMO/supplier is approved in SLP and not expired,
      • Verification parent-child codes match the ERP records,
      • Validation of country permits,
      • Verification of other documents and certificates like GXP relevant, FDA approval, etc.

            If all checks are fine, then PR will be approved, else returned with comments. 

  • PO Creation in Ariba Guided Buying : 
    • A PO is created in Guided Buying and sent to the supplier via SAP Business Network / SCC.
    • It is possible to add conditions to ensure that no PO is created without QA approval. 

Ariba Buying for creating PO

Regulatory Changes  
As part of the "Fiscalization 2.0" project and starting January 2026, the Croatian government is introducing B2B e-invoicing, e-reporting and fiscalization requirements. 

  • B2B/B2G e-invoicing: all businesses with VAT registration in Croatia need to send electronic invoices in the required format through an approved service provider.
  • Fiscalization: 
    • B2B/B2G invoices: issuer and receiver of e-invoices need to send the fiscal data of the invoice to authorities (digitally signed XML). 
    • B2C invoices: issuer of the e-invoice needs to send fiscal to authorities irrespective of payment method (currently required only for cash payments). 
  • E-reporting: in addition to invoicing data (fiscalization), the following reporting requirements need to be fulfilled: 
    • List of collected invoices (payment received), during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of outbound deliveries for which e-invoice could not be delivered, during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer.

entry.title: Tax Code and Amount Not Transferring from SAP to Ariba â€“ Root Cause and Solution
entry.content:
In some situations, suppliers are required to upload and submit their invoices directly through SAP Ariba. Once submitted, these invoices are automatically transferred into SAP S/4HANA for approval and posting.

One of the challenges weâ€™ve identified is that suppliers are required to manually maintain the tax code and taxable amount for every invoice uploaded in Ariba. This approach is far from ideal, it increases the risk of discrepancies and inconsistencies across invoices.

In this post, Iâ€™ll Walk through a solution to address this issue and make the process more accurate, reliable, and efficient.

The issue arises from missing configuration in SAP and incomplete mapping in the integration between SAP and Ariba. Tax details are expected to be transferred through IDocs; however, in this case, the IDocs are not carrying the tax details, 

It is important to note that tax details consist of: Tax code, Tax rate, Taxable amount, and Tax amount.
All of these elements must be accurately transferred and calculated in both SAP and Ariba to ensure the reliability and accuracy of tax invoices submitted by suppliers through the Ariba portal.
Any missing element could potentially lead to the tax details not being transferred accurately.

All Tax details should be transferred from the PO in SAP ERP system to Ariba automatically,

To achieve this, configuration must be done in SAP ERP and in Ariba,

  1. In SAP ERP:
  • For Material PO: send Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 and taxable amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO5.

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 should transfer the below details 

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO5 should transfer the below details

 

  • For Service PO: send the Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 and taxable amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 should transfer the below details

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05 should transfer the below details

 

This configuration ensures that The tax code will be transmitted at the child line-item level of the PO in addition to the main line-item level.

This ensures that tax is calculated for each individual child line item, while maintaining consistency at the main item level.  

Please be aware that the configuration of the Tax details at the main item level should remain as well. 

The tax structure in the PO as it is sent to Ariba should be reflected as follows:

 

  1. In Ariba: Mapping is not possible for this via CIG mapping tool; XSLT mapping should be done.
  • For the service PO: The Payload for the outbound and the pre-processed files of the PO should transfer all tax details as below
               <E1EDC04 SEGMENT="1">

                    <KSCHL>BASB</KSCHL>
                    <KOBTR>500</KOBTR>
                </E1EDC05>

 

  • For Material PO: The Payload for the outbound and the pre-processed files of the PO should transfer all tax details as below
            <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">

                <MSATZ>5</MSATZ>
                <MWSBT>12.5</MWSBT>
            </E1EDP04>

                <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
            </E1EDP05>

 

  1. In Ariba buyer portal: go to the supplier transaction rules and check the below options.

This ensures that while the tax codes and taxable amounts flow directly from SAP, suppliers are prevented from modifying these details when submitting invoices through Ariba

 

Benefits of this configuration consists of:

  • Significantly reduces discrepancies and rejected invoices.

entry.title: What is Adoption?
entry.content:
As a former customer turned SAP employee dedicated to adoption, I hear some very different ideas about what adoption actually is.  It seems to mean something very different to almost every customer Iâ€™ve spoken with (over 100 at this point)!  So letâ€™s clear the fog and attempt to create a working definition of adoption!

_______________________________________________________________

First, What Adoption Is Not

  • Not just the starting line. Marathon running for instance involves preparation, a starting line, a finish line, and in between a lot of hard work. Similarly, the day you â€œgo liveâ€ is the starting line, not the finish line. You have to run the entire race!
  • Not â€œour users seem happy.â€ Sentiment is helpful but measurable business outcomes are the stuff of gold medals.
  • Not just a dashboard of random metrics. 1,000 logins are great but 3 automated processes that cut cycle time in half are better.
  • Not a once-and-done project. As your business, your processes, and your roadmap evolve; adoption is a continuous discipline.

_______________________________________________________________

Soâ€¦ What Is Adoption?

Adoption is the strategic, ongoing process of turning your SAP software into everyday business results. It goes beyond initial deployment to drive full, meaningful engagement across your organizationâ€”so you realize the value you bought, renew with confidence, and double-down on what works. Letâ€™s review adoption as three components.

1) Depth and Breadth of Usage

Great adoption means your team uses the right capabilities deeplyâ€”and enough teams use them broadlyâ€”to create enterprise-wide impact.

  • Depth: Youâ€™re not just approving POs or reviewing timesheetsâ€”youâ€™re using game- changing features like Guided Buying for SAP Ariba or SOW Bid for SAP Fieldglass. The features & functions that move the needle are the ones tied to specific value drivers such as price reduction, efficiency, quality, and compliance.
  • Breadth: Procurement, Finance, Operations, HR, and field teams all participate making workflows across what was once a siloâ€™d organization. Swivel chair processes are gone. Handoffs are digital, not manual.

Signs youâ€™re winning:

  • Feature usage moves from â€œcoreâ€ capabilities to advanced.
  • Multiple business areas participate in endâ€‘toâ€‘end workflows (not isolated tasks).
  • Efficiency metrics improve: cycle time â†“, rework â†“, compliance â†‘.

Benefit: Your process becomes a case study in total transformation not just another software deployment.

2) Consumption Aligned to Entitlement

Youâ€™ve matched what you own (spend/users/modules) with what you actually useâ€”so value is realized, not left on the table.

  • You avoid shelfware by activating highâ€‘value modules youâ€™ve already paid for (and most likely justified with a business case).
  • Usage equals value. Your consumption patterns justify renewals and make the case for expansion.

Signs youâ€™re winning:

  • License utilization aligns with the contract & business need.
  • Shelfware is activated with a plan.
  • Stakeholders can see a clear story of investing â€œxâ€ to get â€œyâ€.

Benefit: The ROI is predictable & justified from a budget perspective because results are tangible.

3) Value Achieved

Adoption is measured by business results, not just the number of logins.

  • Efficiency: cycle time, touchless processing.
  • Compliance: policy adherence and audit readiness.
  • Cost/price: realized savings and cost avoidance.
  • Quality: candidates for SAP Fieldglass are up to the challenge

Signs youâ€™re winning:

  • KPIs tie to executive priorities.
  • Value is repeatable and attributable to specific SAP-enabled scenarios.
  • Leaders want to know, â€œWhat else can we automate?â€

Benefit: SAP solutions become an engine for transformation and growth. SAP is a valued and trusted partner.

_______________________________________________________________

A Practical 90â€‘Day Adoption Game Plan

  1. Start with value. Identify 3â€“5 outcomes (e.g., reduce invoice cycle time by 30%, increase spend under management by 15%).
  2. Map value to capability. Which capabilities make those outcomes real? (e.g., SAP Fieldglass Rate guidance or SOW bids.  SAP Ariba Guided Buying, a well-defined supplier risk process.)
  3. Activate champions by role. Procurement, AP, HR, and Operations, each need a champion with a playbook and a plan.
  4. Configure KPIs & measure them early so you can see adoption in real time.
  5. Show the score. Publish a simple, clear scorecard; spotlight improvements and highlight bottlenecks.
  6. Scale what works. Turn the first wins into success stories; communicate and repeat what works across teams/regions.
  7. Run regular adoption health checks. Which areas of the business need more help? Who deserves an innovation award?

_______________________________________________________________

Adoption done right . . .

So how are you running the race of adoption? Does your preparation phase need help? Do you need help getting from mile 13 to 20? When adoption is done right, your SAP solutions become the way your business runsâ€”faster, smarter, with endurance & purpose.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2511 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Community, We're thrilled to share great new innovations in our upcoming release, 2511 with a strong focus on improved management of service requisitioning and overall UX improvements in Guided Buying. We are also pleased to share expanded capability in SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app and improved user experience for catalog administrators, we hope you enjoy the highlights.

Support for Hierarchical Service Items in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-300)

Complex service procurements (for example, a laptop repair plus software maintenance and a parts kit) traditionally generate multiple requisitions, followâ€‘ups and approval cycles.

Service hierarchies let your teams create a single, coherent requisition that models the real delivery structure of work and items. That reduces administrative overhead, shortens cycle time to order, and gives finance and procurement better visibility into bundled spend â€” all of which translate to faster time-to-value and lower operational cost.

Child items can include catalog and non-catalog services or goods. For example, you can create a non-catalog request for laptop repair service (parent service) and then add software maintenance service (child item) and computer cleaning kit (child item).

Service hierarchies help to define how services are structured and delivered, improving efficiency when ordering services.

You can use service hierarchies in the following scenarios:

  • When you create a service requisition using a non-catalog request or a line item form, you can add child items using the Add Child Item button.
  • On the checkout page, you can add child items to the request before you submit it.
  • If you submit a service requistion, you can withdraw it after it's submitted or partially approved, add child items, and then resubmit it.

When you create a non-catalog request for a service, the Add Child Item button, Expected Amount, and Max Amount display on the form, as shown in the following figure:

 The following figure displays a hierarchical service request:

 

This feature can be enabled through the following parameter:

PARAM_ENABLE_NON_CATALOG_SERVICE_HIERARCHY which enables service hierarchies for non-catalog requests and line item forms.

 

Hide Interim Supplier RFQ Bids (GUIDEB-1262)

You can now configure Guided Buying to hide interim supplier RFQ bids from users and display only awarded bids.

By default, guided buying displays all bids to users. However, taking onboard your feedback, some customers may prefer to hide interim bids and display only the winning bid after it has been awarded.

This capability is available only in high-touch RFQ scenarios, where professional buyers evaluate and award bids in SAP Ariba Sourcing.

If you enable this feature there will be some subtle changes to the UI in the following screens:

  • Receive quotes
  • Awarding
  • Confirm award
  • Bid overview section
  • Compare bids (both graph and table view)

You can enable this capability by setting a new guided buying parameter PARAM_ENABLE_HIDE_BIDS_IN_HIGH_TOUCH to true.

For more information about configuring API communication, see Guided Buying Parameters for RFQs

 

Display Requisition Amount in Approver's or Watcher's Currency (PROC-1029)

Given the global nature of business these days it's quite likely approvers may be overseas, to simplify this experience for an approver we have introduced the ability to display requisition amount upon approval in the approver (or watchers) preferred/default currency.

New fields such as Total in Your Currency at the header level and Amount in Your Currency at the line level are displayed for a requisition when the requisition is sent for approval:

 Your administrator can enable the through the following parameter: PARAM_ENABLE_APPROVERS_AMOUNT_IN_LOCAL_CURRENCY

 

Support for Budget Check in External ERP System for SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App Requisitions (BMAA-479)

Its always important to know if your cost centre has sufficient budget to allow your requisition and corresponding PO to be created. We have now expanded requisition budget check capability to the SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app too.

In the SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app, real-time budget check is performed in the external ERP system (normally the source to check the budget against the requisition) when users submit or withdraw requisitions, and also when requisitions are approved or denied.

To enable this capability your administrator can enable the parameter: Application.Mobile.EnableRTBCInExternalERPSystem

 

Enhancements to Catalog Replication Page (CMS-1418)

With this feature, the Catalog Replication page contains a new tab called Content that allows catalog administrators to search for catalogs quickly. The new design optimizes browsing and viewing large volumes of data.

Previously, the Catalog Replication page loaded all the catalogs in the Overview and Configuration tabs, which made it difficult for users to search for catalogs.

A new tab called Content is now displayed on the Catalog Replication page. As a catalog administrator, you can search for a catalog by its name and type (subscribed or unsubscribed). By default, the number of catalogs displayed on the page is limited to 1000.

We are happy today to have covered an important set of features to benefit end users, approvers and also catalog administrators with the aim to streamline work by presenting the right information front and centre to get the job done quickly and efficiently throughout the buying process.

entry.title: Adoption Isnâ€™t a Phase, Itâ€™s a Relationship
entry.content:
If you know me, you know I love an analogy. Itâ€™s always helpful to make new information make sense by likening it to something we already understand.

In my role here at SAP, I talk about adoption a lot. Itâ€™s a point that I (and my wonderful team, Solution Value Advisory) really push with our customers, who sometimes think of adoption as a step in the overall process, something you do after go-live.  So, my analogy for today is to look at adoption like a relationship, because itâ€™s never just about the software, but about the people and how they interact with the system and each other.

Itâ€™s not much of a stretch, really. At the start, itâ€™s a mix of excitement, a little confusion, and commitment that comes with bringing something new into your life, and hoping it thrives, grows, and has the support of people around you.


The honeymoon stage
 In my last role several years back, I worked on Ariba solution implementations. Being on a shared services team, I got to stick my hands into a lot of different customersâ€™ Ariba deployments. It felt great, for the customer and for me, to reach what felt like a finish line: go-live. That point of the new solution(s) going live after months of setup and testing. The vibes were always good - everyone was hopeful, users explored the system, performed tests. Teams got trained. There was that spark of possibility, that sense of this time, things will be different.

But just like any new relationship, the shine fades if the day-to-day connection isnâ€™t nurtured. Old habits creep back in, shortcuts resurface. And, before long, that beautiful new tool starts gathering dust.  Remember, adoption doesnâ€™t end at go-live, thatâ€™s when it begins.


Relationships thrive on consistency, and so do systems
Healthy adoption looks a lot like a healthy partnership: steady, intentional, and full of small moments that build trust.

Itâ€™s when someone logs in and sees that their preferences were remembered. Itâ€™s when data syncs across systems, so people stop fighting with spreadsheets and endless back-and-forth email. Itâ€™s when users realize the tool makes their jobs easier, not harder. It keeps the relationship alive.

But breakdowns donâ€™t usually happen with a bang, but a fizzle. Users donâ€™t revolt, they quietly disengage. They skip the process â€œjust this once.â€ Then they stop trusting the data, because the process is getting skipped and they canâ€™t find what they were looking for. And now something that was originally set up to create efficiency is now only causing frustration, and becomes a pain in theâ€¦well, you know. ğŸ˜Š

In my work with customers, I see this all the time.  I work a lot with customers on their supplier management processes especially, and I see a lot of this disengagement when it comes to onboarding. Tools like SAP Cloud Identity Services and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle & Performance (SLP) can be super powerful, but they depend on trusted data and consistency. If people donâ€™t understand why something matters, they wonâ€™t invest in making it work.

The love language of AI is good data
Now weâ€™re entering a new chapter, one where AI tools like SAP Joule are ready to help make our jobs easier. But even Joule, which might seem like magic when you see it presented, needs a foundation of trust. This has been my main message of the year - reminding people that AI doesnâ€™t make magic out of thin air, rather it builds on what we give it. If data is messy, disconnected, or if established processes are underused, Jouleâ€™s insights will be, too.

(Pausing here for a shoutout to anyone who was at the Customer Success Day in NYC earlier this year where I did a whole session to essentially say, â€œGarbage in, garbage outâ€. The highlight, at least to me, was my AI-generated Ariba song parody of Naughty by Natureâ€™s O.P.P.  Whoâ€™s down with SLP? Yeah you know me!)

But back to my relationship analogy, think of it this way: if you never talk to your partner, you canâ€™t expect them to finish your sentences. Joule works the same way. The relationship only deepens when we communicate through connected, clean, and well-adopted systems. 


Adoption is ongoing care.
As I said before, adoption isnâ€™t a task. We donâ€™t â€œcompleteâ€ adoption. We maintain it. We check in with our users, we update them on changes, and we listen when something isnâ€™t working and adjust before resentment sets in.  The most successful customers I see are those who treat adoption as a living process. Not just implementing technology, but inviting it into their company culture. When adoption is healthy, everything else (innovation, automation, AI, etc.) starts to flow naturally.  But just like any great relationship, it takes attention, empathy, and patience.


I encourage you all to stay in tune with our roadmap, as thereâ€™s a lot of exciting stuff to come in 2026 when it comes to AI in SAP. But as you read up on that and start to think how cool it will be and how much time it will save to have all of those new capabilities, remember that now is the time to build the foundation for that new relationship. 

If you have any doubts about how well your company is adopting your solutions and how youâ€™re doing on usage in comparison to other customers, do reach out to your CSM who can either help, or can pull in the right people to have that conversation. Sometimes that person is me, so say hi and maybe I'll share my library of Ariba song parodies.

entry.title: Achieving Best-in-Class Invoice Exception KPIs in SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing
entry.content:
One of the clearest indicators of efficiency in an AP organization is the percentage of invoices that can be processed without an exception. Best-in-class performers consistently achieve 85â€“90% (or higher) invoice-throughput with zero exceptions. Many SAP Ariba customers operate far below thatâ€”often without realizing how much time, cost, and user frustration gets tied up in exception handling.

As part of the SAP Ariba Solution Value Advisory team, we work with customers every day to improve adoption and unlock measurable business value. And one consistent theme we see?
Within SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing or SAP Ariba Invoice Management,  when the â€œinvoices without exceptionsâ€ KPI is low, itâ€™s usually a sign that key reporting insights or powerful configuration options arenâ€™t being fully leveraged. Many customers set these tolerances and exception rules at their go-live and never revisit themâ€”even as their supplier base, purchasing patterns, and business priorities evolve. The good news is that by analyzing the right reports and adjusting targeted configuration settings, this KPI can be improved quickly and sustainably.

Letâ€™s walk through why this matters, what you should measure, and how to improve it using SAP Ariba best practices.

Why This KPI Matters

Improving your exception-free invoice rate isnâ€™t just about efficiencyâ€”it directly impacts:

1. Faster Invoice Cycle Times

Fewer exceptions mean fewer delays. Suppliers get paid quicker. AP teams get out of firefighting mode.

2. Stronger Supplier Relationships

Consistent processing builds trust, predictability, and reduces the back-and-forth inquiries.

3. Lower Operating Cost

Exception handling is expensive. Every unnecessary rework loop adds labor hours.

4. Better User Experience

Buyers, receivers, and AP processors spend less time resolving issues and more time on strategic work.

5. Clean Data Feeding Analytics & Automation

A cleaner invoice process unlocks more opportunities for automation, validations, and future optimization.

Step 1: Measure Whatâ€™s Really Happening

Before solving problems, you need a clear look at them.

I always recommend customers start by running the following in SAP Ariba:

Exception Reports by:

  • Exception type

  • Supplier

  • Commodity

This gives a precise view of where your exceptions are coming from. Often, 80% of issues originate from 10â€“15 suppliers or a handful of commodities.

This becomes your roadmap.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Supplier

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Supplier

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each supplier.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Commodity

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Commodity

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each Commodity L2.

Interpret the Results and Identify Where to Act

Once youâ€™ve run your exception reports by supplier and commodity, the real value comes from how you use the findings. This is where customers often unlock quick wins.

Start by reviewing:

  • Which suppliers generate the highest number of exceptions

  • Which commodities consistently trigger the same exception types

  • Patterns across PO types or line items

In most organizations, a small group of suppliers or categories is responsible for the majority of exceptions. This makes your next steps much more focused and targeted.

Use the Data to Drive Configuration Improvements

If you see that receiving exceptions are concentrated around certain suppliers or commodities, this is a strong indicator that your receiving process may not fit how those suppliers operate. For example, many high-volume, fast-shipping suppliers (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, IT accessories, etc.) ship and invoice so quickly that end users rarely have time to receive the items manually.

This is exactly where SAP Aribaâ€™s configuration options can help.

Step 2: Strategy & Configuration Options to Improve Your KPI

Below are the most effective levers that customers have used to reduce invoice exceptions and move toward best-in-class performance.

1. Use Auto-Receiving for High-Velocity, Low-Risk Suppliers

If you see a high volume of receiving exceptions for certain suppliersâ€”especially those who ship quickly (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, safety, IT peripherals)â€”auto-receiving can significantly improve your throughput.

Why this works

Many of these suppliers ship and invoice same-day. That leaves almost no time for end users to receive goods manually. Auto-receipt ensures:

  • Fewer receiving exceptions

  • Faster invoice processing

  • Less burden on casual users

How to configure

Auto-receiving can be based on:

  • Supplier & Supplier Part Number or by only Supplier 

  • Commodity

2. Review and Adjust Tax Exception Tolerances

Tax exceptions are common, especially in jurisdictions where suppliers calculate tax differently or round amounts differently.

How to improve

  • Review your current tax variance tolerances

  • Identify suppliers consistently triggering small variances

  • Adjust tolerances to realistic levels aligned with procurement policy

This can be strategically relaxed only where justifiedâ€”not globally.

3. Evaluate Shipping Cost Tolerances

Shipping exceptions often occur when:

  • The supplier charges small shipping amounts not included on the PO 

  • When outside a stated percentage tolerance of the invoice amount

Options

  • Set reasonable shipping % tolerances

  • Use flat-rate dollar tolerances for specific suppliers

  • Update templates for certain commodities where shipping is always variable

4. Leverage Invoice Exception Overrides (By Supplier or Commodity)

This is one of the most under-used but highly effective tools SAP Ariba customers have.

What They Are

Invoice exception overrides allow you to set:

  • Different tolerance percentages

  • Different dollar limits

For specific suppliers, commodity codes, or currency.

Why It Matters

Most exceptions are not systemicâ€”they are concentrated. Overrides let you tune the system where the problem exists, without weakening global controls.

Examples

  • For a trusted supplier with a predictable pattern, allow a slightly higher price variance.

  • For a commodity where tax always fluctuates (e.g., services), apply more flexible thresholds.

  • Ensure to adjust amount tolerances per currency

5. Work With Suppliers When Exceptions Follow a Pattern

Sometimes exceptions are not a configuration issue, but a supplier process issue.

Consider supplier-facing improvements such as:

  • Reinforcing PO-Flip usage

  • Ensuring suppliers invoice based on PO quantities only

  • Updating supplier enablement documentation

  • Aligning catalog pricing with contracts

  • Negotiating tax and shipping behavior

Rememberâ€”suppliers want faster invoice processing too.

Step 3: Communicate Improvements and Track Progress

Once youâ€™ve implemented changes, measure the impact:

  • Exception rate by supplier month-over-month

  • Top 10 exception drivers (before vs. after)

  • Auto-receive success rates

  • Percentage reduction in tax/shipping exceptions

Customers who follow this approach typically see:

  • 20â€“40% reduction in exceptions within 90 days

  • Major improvements in user satisfaction

  • A measurable boost in straight-through invoice processing

Final Thoughts

Improving your â€œinvoices without exceptionsâ€ KPI is not about relaxing controlsâ€”itâ€™s about applying the right controls in the right places. The strategies in this article come directly from working with many SAP Ariba customers, across industries, who have successfully increased adoption and reduced AP workload through targeted process and configuration optimization.

If your KPI is below best-in-class, use this as a starting point. A few focused adjustments can create a major lift in processing speed, supplier satisfaction, and AP efficiency.

entry.title: Nonâ€‘PO Invoices: When to Use Them and When Not
entry.content:
Invoices submitted without a reference to a purchase order or a contract are common in many organizations. For their lack of reference, they are referred as non-PO Invoices in the invoice processing systems across the AP scope.

Nonâ€‘PO invoices solve real problems but also introduce risks. In this short guide I'm trying to explain how often they are used, when they make sense, what risks they represent, and practical actions to be taken by procurement leaders.

How much theyâ€™re used

Typical usage of non-PO invoices by organizations lies in 5â€“30% interval of invoice volume and 5â€“25% of AP spend. This can differ per industry segments, but higher ratios exceeding 30% may be indicators of slow PO processes, high services spend, many small vendors, or immature procurement systems. For organizations it points to opportunities for improvements in their efficiency and compliance targets.

When nonâ€‘PO invoices make sense

There are cases, where non-PO invoices are unavoidable and include number of scenarios that can be handled without loosing control:

  • Emergency or safetyâ€‘critical purchases where creating a PO would cause unwanted delays
  • Professional services billed on milestones, time & materials, or when scope/price is agreed after work begins
    (unless they are covered by contracts to which the invoices could be referring to)
  • Suppliers that cannot accept POs (small/legacy suppliers in challenging regions)
  • Very lowâ€‘value transactions where PO overhead exceeds benefit
  • Highly exceptional cases, when PO cannot be created, e.g. system outages, transitions, etc.

When nonâ€‘PO invoices are NOT a good practice

Sometimes organizations keep their "long term" legacy practices, because "it is so comfortable to do it our time-proven way". Many opportunities can be missed, more manual effort in the invoice matching activities is required, and organizations tend to run in circles, unable to unlock the trap.

Try to avoid the following (or similar) areas, where non-PO invoices are part of the picture:  

  • Repeat purchases from the same supplier that should be on contract or catalog
  • Highâ€‘value or strategic spend where PO terms protect pricing, delivery and liability
  • Categories with clear opportunities for consolidation or volume discounts
  • Environments with known fraud or duplicate payment risk and weak AP controls

When there is an overlay between the existing structured buying channels (catalog/contract spend), or guarding commercial terms (payment/delivery/liability), non-PO invoices can be easily replaced. This will deliver efficiency improvements. 

Pros and cons

Decision makers in the procurement organizations might be aware of the positive and negative aspects of the non-PO invoice practice in their purchasing processes. Here is the overview:

  •  Pros
    • Speed and flexibility for urgent or complex purchases
    • Preserves supplier relationships when suppliers wonâ€™t accept POs
    • Simpler for T&M or milestone invoicing for services (if tools for contract compliance/services spend are unavailable)
  • Cons
    • Higher maverick spend, weak spend control
    • Low visibility into budget, contracts and supplier performance
    • Higher AP processing costs and more invoice exceptions
    • Increased risk of fraud or duplicate payments
    • Slower monthâ€‘end reconciliation and weaker sourcing discipline

Practical policy decisions and actions

  1. Define acceptable exceptions
    • Publish a short list of allowed cases (emergency, validated supplier, lowâ€‘value threshold, services)
    • require a business justification field on every nonâ€‘PO invoice

  2. Set clear thresholds & approval matrix
    • Use amount thresholds tied to approval levels
      (e.g., Dept Manager for <500; Directorfor<5k; Procurement+Finance for larger amounts)
  3. Automate nonâ€‘PO workflows
    • Force mandatory fields (exception reason, GL code, cost center)
    • Route approvals automatically, and capture justification in the AR/AP system

  4. Monitor & report monthly
    • Track count and value of nonâ€‘PO invoices, repeat suppliers, timeâ€‘toâ€‘approval, and % of total AP spend
    • Create alerts for repeat nonâ€‘PO suppliers

  5. Convert repeat nonâ€‘PO spend
    • Onboard frequent nonâ€‘PO suppliers to catalogs, negotiated contracts or a managed marketplace (SpotBuy) within 60â€“90 days

  6. Strengthen supplier onboarding
    • Ensure vendors used for nonâ€‘PO invoices have basic validations (tax forms, bank details, insurance) before payments over a threshold

  7. Balance convenience with control
    • Offer lowâ€‘friction PO alternatives (catalogs, SpotBuy, preâ€‘approved templates) to reduce the need of nonâ€‘PO invoices

  8. Audit & continuous improvement
    • Periodically audit samples of nonâ€‘PO invoices for compliance, fraud indicators and opportunities to source differently

Quick target benchmarks 

How do you know, where you stand and whether you are successful in achieving your targets? You might want to use this simple guide of measurable process metrics to help you gain visibility of the non-PO invoicing process:

  • Healthy: nonâ€‘PO invoice volume <15% and nonâ€‘PO spend <10% of AP
  • Risky: nonâ€‘PO invoice volume 15â€“30% or nonâ€‘PO spend 10â€“25% â€” implement remediation plan
  • Alarm: nonâ€‘PO invoice volume >30% or nonâ€‘PO spend >25% â€” immediate controls, audit, and supplier enablement required

 

Final takeaway

Nonâ€‘PO invoices should be a controlled exception, not the norm. Make sure to limit their use with a clear policy, automate approvals and data capture, track them closely, and convert recurring nonâ€‘PO purchases into POâ€‘based channels where better savings, visibility and control can be delivered.
